article.title: Czech_language

template.arg: {{Legend|#0080ff|regions where Czech is the language of the majority}} {{Legend|#88c4ff|regions where Czech is the language of a significant minority}}

article.paragraph: Czech(IPAc-enˈtʃɛk;etinaIPA-csˈt͡ʃɛʃcɪna), formerly known asBohemiancite webCzech languagehttp://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/149048/Czech-languagewww.britannica.comEncyclopædia Britannica6 January 2015(IPAc-enbəʊˈhiːmɪən;lingua BohemicainLatin), is aWest Slavic languagesWest Slavic languagespoken by over 10 million people. It is the official language in theCzech Republic(where most of its speakers live), and hasminority languagestatus inSlovakia. Czech's closest relative isSlovak languageSlovak, with which it ismutual intelligibilitymutually intelligible. It is closely related to other West Slavic languages, such asSilesian languageSilesianandPolish languagePolish, and more distantly toEast Slavic languagessuch asRussian languageRussian. Although most Czech vocabulary is based on shared roots withSlavic languagesSlavicand otherIndo-European languages, many loanwords (most associated withhigh culture) have been adopted in recent years.

The language began in its present linguistic branch as Old Czech before slowly dwindling in importance, dominated byGerman languageGermanin theCzech lands. During the mid-eighteenth century, it experienced aCzech National Revivalrevivalin which Czech academics stressed the past accomplishments of their people and advocated the return of Czech as a major language. It has changed little since this time, except for minormorphology (linguistics)morphologicalshifts and the formalization ofCommon Czechcolloquialelements.

Itsphonemeinventory is moderate in size, comprising five vowels (eachVowel lengthshort or long) and twenty-five consonants (divided into "hard", "neutral" and "soft" categories). Words may contain uncommon (or complicated) consonant clusters, includingVoiced alveolar raised non-sonorant trillone consonantrepresented by thegrapheme, or lack vowels altogether. Czechorthographyis simple, and has been used as a model byphonologyphonologists.

As a member of the Slavic sub-family of the Indo-European languages, Czech is a highlyinflectioninflectedfusional language. Its nouns and adjectives undergo a complex system ofdeclensionforgrammatical casecase,grammatical numbernumber,grammatical gendergender,animacyand type of ending consonant (hard, neutral or soft). Verbs (withgrammatical aspectaspect) aregrammatical conjugationconjugatedsomewhat more simply for tense, number and gender. Because of this inflection, Czechword orderis very flexible and words may be transposed to change emphasis or form questions.
article.heading: Classification
article.paragraph: File:Slavic languages tree.svgthumbright350pxalt=Language-tree graphClassification of Czech within theBalto-Slavic languagesBalto-Slavicbranch of the Indo-European language family. Czech and Slovak make up a "CzechSlovak" subgroup.Czech is classified as a member of theWest Slavic languagesWest Slavicsub-branch of theSlavic languagesSlavicbranch of theIndo-European languagesIndo-Europeanlanguage family. This branch includesPolish languagePolish,Kashubian languageKashubian,Upper SorbianUpperandLower SorbianandSlovak languageSlovak. Slovak is by far the closest genetic neighbor of Czech, and the languages are closer than any other pair of West Slavic languages (including Upper and Lower Sorbian, which share a name by association with anSorbsethnic group).HarvnbSussexCubberley201154–56

The West Slavic languages are spoken in an area classified as part of Central Europe. Except for Polish they differ fromEast Slavic languagesEastandSouth Slavic languagesby their initial-syllable stress, and from other West Slavic languages by a more-restricted distinction between "hard" and "soft" consonants (see#PhonologyPhonologybelow).
article.heading: Mutual intelligibility
article.paragraph: MainComparison of Slovak and CzechCzech and Slovak have been consideredmutual intelligibilitymutually intelligible; speakers of either language can communicate with greater ease than those of any other pair of West Slavic languages. Since thedissolution of Czechoslovakiamutual intelligibility has declined for younger speakers, probably because Czech speakers now experience less exposure to Slovak and vice versa.sfnShort2009306

The languages have not undergone the deliberate highlighting of minor linguistic differences in the name of nationalism as has occurred in theBosnian languageBosnian,Serbian languageSerbianandCroatian languageCroatianstandards ofSerbo-Croatian. However, most Slavic languages (including Czech) have been distanced in this way fromRussian languageRussianinfluences because of widespread public resentment against the formerSoviet Union(whichWarsaw Pact invasion of CzechoslovakiaoccupiedCzechoslovakiain 1968).HarvnbSussexCubberley201158–59Czech and Slovak form adialect continuum, with great similarity between neighboring Czech and Slovak dialects.(See "#DialectsDialects" below.)

In phonetic differences, Czech is characterized by aglottal stopbefore initial vowels and Slovak by its less-frequent use of long vowels than Czech;HarvnbSussexCubberley201157–58however, Slovak has long forms of the consonantsrandlwhen they function as vowels.HarvnbEsposito201183Phonemic differences between the two languages are generally consistent, typical of two dialects of a language. Grammatically, although Czech (unlike Slovak) has avocative caseboth languages share a common syntax.

One study showed that Czech and Slovaklexiconsdiffered by 80 percent, but this high percentage was found to stem primarily from differing orthographies and slight inconsistencies in morphological formation;HarvnbEsposito201182Slovak morphology is more regular (when changing from thenominative casenominativeto thelocative case,PraguePra'''h'''abecomesPrazein Czech andPrahein Slovak). The two lexicons are generally considered similar, with most differences in colloquial vocabulary and some scientific terminology. Slovak has slightly more borrowed words than Czech.

The similarities between Czech and Slovak led to the languages being considered a single language by a group of 19th-century scholars who called themselves "Czechoslavs" (echoslovci), believing that the peoples were connected in a way which excludedGerman Bohemiansand (to a lesser extent)Hungarian peopleHungariansand other Slavs.HarvnbMaxwell2009101–105During theFirst Czechoslovak Republic(19181938), although "Czechoslovak" was designated as the republic's official language both Czech and Slovak written standards were used. Standard written Slovak was partially modeled on literary Czech, and Czech was preferred for some official functions in the Slovak half of the republic. Czech influence on Slovak was protested by Slovak scholars, and when Slovakia broke off from Czechoslovakia in 1938 as theSlovak Republic (19391945)Slovak State(which then aligned withNazi GermanyinWorld War II) literary Slovak was deliberately distanced from Czech. When theAxis powerslost the war and Czechoslovakia reformed, Slovak developed somewhat on its own (with Czech influence); during thePrague Springof 1968, Slovak gained independence from (and equality with) Czech.Since then, "Czechoslovak" refers to improvisedpidginsof the languages which have arisen from the decrease in mutual intelligibility.cite webhttp://www.researchgate.net/publication/240751085_Closely-related_languages_in_contact_Czech_Slovak_Czechoslovak''International Journal of the Sociology of Language''NábělkováMiraClosely-related languages in contact: Czech, Slovak, "Czechoslovak"January 2007August 18, 2014yes
article.heading: History

link.part: TheBible of Kralicewas the first completeBible translations into Czechtranslation of the Bible into the Czech language. Its six volumes were first published between 1579 and 1593.
alt=A Gothic-style book with ornate, flowery designs on the cover

article.heading: Origins: Proto-Czech and Old Czech
article.paragraph: see alsoHistory of the Czech landsAround the sixth century AD, a tribe ofSlavic peoplesSlavsarrived in a portion of Central Europe. According to legend they were led by a hero namedLech, ech and Rusech, from whom the word "Czech" derives. The ninth century brought the state ofGreat Moravia, whose first ruler (Rastislav of Moravia) invitedByzantine EmpireByzantinerulerMichael IIIto send missionaries in an attempt to reduce the influence ofEast Franciaon religious and political life in his country. These missionaries,Constantine and Methodius, helped to convert theCzechsfromSlavic mythologytraditional Slavic paganismtoChristianityand established a church system. They also brought theGlagolitic alphabetto the West Slavs, whose language was previously unwritten.HarvnbSussexCubberley201198This language, later known as Proto-Czech, was beginning to separate from its fellow West Slavic hatchlings Proto-Slovak, Proto-Polish and Proto-Sorbian. Among other features, Proto-Czech was marked by its ephemeral use of thevoiced velar fricativeconsonant (//)HarvnbLibermanTrubetskoi2001112and consistent stress on the first syllable.HarvnbLibermanTrubetskoi2001153

The Czechs' language separated from other Slavic tongues into what would later be called Old Czech by the thirteenth century, a classification extending through the sixteenth century.Its use ofGrammatical casecasesdiffered from the modern language; although Old Czech did not yet have avocative caseHarvnbMann195759or ananimacydistinction,declensionfor its six cases and three genders rapidly became complicated (partially to differentiate homophones)HarvnbMann195761–62and its declension patterns resembled those ofLithuanian languageLithuanian(its Balto-Slavic cousin).

File:Stimmer Jan Hus.jpgthumbJan HusWhile Old Czech had a basic alphabet from which a general set of orthographical correspondences was drawn, it did not have a standard orthography.HarvnbPiotrowski201295It also contained a number of sound clusters which no longer exist; allowing(/j/) after soft consonants, which has since shifted toe(//),HarvnbMann195759–60and allowing complex consonant clusters to be pronounced all at once rather thansyllabic consonantsyllabically.cite webhttp://www.phil.muni.cz/linguistica/art/scheer/ScheerSyllTrappConsFDSL5.pdfPDFSyllabic and trapped consonants in (Western) Slavic: different but still the sameScheerTobias[[Masaryk University]]August 10, 2014A phonological phenomenon,Havlik's law(which began inProto-Slavicand took various forms in other Slavic languages), appeared in Old Czech; counting backwards from the end of a clause, every odd-numberedyerwas vocalized as a vowel, while the other yers disappeared.HarvnbScheer2004505

Bohemia (as Czech civilization was known by then) increased in power over the centuries, as its language did in regional importance. This growth was expedited during the fourteenth century byCharles IV, Holy Roman EmperorHoly Roman Emperor Charles IV, who foundedCharles University in Praguein 1348. Here, early Czech literature (aBible translations into Czechbiblical translation, hymns andhagiography) flourished.Old Czech texts, including poetry and cookbooks, were produced outside the university as well.Later in the centuryJan Huscontributed significantly to the standardization ofCzech orthography, advocated for widespread literacy among Czech commoners (particularly in religion) and made early efforts to model written Czech after the spoken language.HarvnbSussexCubberley201198–99

Czech continued to evolve and gain in regional importance for hundreds of years,HarvnbCernaMachalek200726and has been a literary language in theSlovak landssince the early fifteenth century.cite webhttp://homepages.uni-tuebingen.de/tilman.berger/Publikationen/CzechSlovak.pdfSlovaks in Czechia – Czechs in Slovakia[[University of Tübingen]]BergerTilmanPDFAugust 9, 2014A biblical translation, theKralice Bible, was published during the late sixteenth century (around the time of theKing James BibleKing JamesandLuther BibleLutherversions) which was more linguistically conservative than either. The publication of the Kralice Bible spawned widespreadnationalism, and in 1615 the government of Bohemia ruled that only Czech-speaking residents would be allowed to become full citizens or inherit goods or land. This, and the conversion of the Czech upper classes from theHabsburg Empire'sCatholicismtoProtestantism, angered the Habsburgs and helped trigger theThirty Years' War(where the Czechs were defeated at theBattle of White Mountain). The Czechs becameserfdomserfs; Bohemia's printing industry (and its linguistic and political rights) were dismembered, removing official regulation and support from its language.HarvnbSussexCubberley201199–100German languageGermanquickly became the dominant language in Bohemia.
article.heading: Revival: Modern Czech
article.paragraph: File:Jan Vilmek - Josef Dobrovsk.jpgthumbrightJosef Dobrovsk, whose writing played a key role in reviving Czech as a written languagealt=In a detailed pencil sketch, a middle-aged man in a suit looks idly into the distance.see alsoCzech National RevivalThe consensus among linguists is that modern, standard Czech originated during the eighteenth century.HarvnbChloupekNekvapil199392By then the language had developed a literary tradition, and since then it has changed little; journals from that period have no substantial differences from modern standard Czech, and contemporary Czechs can understand them with little difficulty.HarvnbChloupekNekvapil199395Changes include theMorphology (linguistics)morphologicalshift oftoejandto(althoughsurvives for some uses) and the merging ofand the formerej.HarvnbChloupekNekvapil199393Sometime before the eighteenth century, the Czech language abandoned a distinction between phonemic /l/ and // which survives in Slovak.

link.part: Prohibition signs written in Czech, by entry #3 into the building of National Technical Library in Prague.

article.paragraph: TheCzechsCzech peoplegained widespread national pride during the mid-eighteenth century, inspired by theAge of Enlightenmenta half-century earlier. Czech historians began to emphasize their people's accomplishments from the fifteenth through the seventeenth centuries, rebelling against theCounter-Reformation(which had denigrated Czech and other non-Latin languageLatinlanguages).HarvnbAgnew1994250CzechPhilologyphilologistsstudied sixteenth-century texts, advocating the return of the language tohigh culture.HarvnbAgnew1994251–252This period is known as the Czech National RevivalHarvnbWilson200918(or Renascence).

During the revival, in 1809 linguist and historianJosef Dobrovskreleased a German-language grammar of Old Czech entitledAusfrliches Lehrgebude der bhmischen Sprache(Comprehensive Doctrine of the Bohemian Language). Dobrovsk had intended his book to bedescriptive linguisticsdescriptive, and did not think Czech had a realistic chance of returning as a major language. However,Josef Jungmannand other revivalists used Dobrovsk's book to advocate for a Czech linguistic revival.Changes during this time included spelling reform (notably,in place of the formerjandjin place ofg), the use oft(rather thanti) to end infinitive verbs and the non-capitalization of nouns (which had been a late borrowing from German).HarvnbMaxwell2009106These changes differentiated Czech from Slovak.HarvnbChloupekNekvapil199396Modern scholars disagree about whether the conservative revivalists were motivated by nationalism or considered contemporary spoken Czech unsuitable for formal, widespread use.

Adherence to historical patterns was later relaxed and standard Czech adopted a number of features fromCommon Czech(a widespread, informalRegister (sociolinguistics)register), such as leaving some proper nouns undeclined. This has resulted in a relatively high level of homogeneity among all varieties of the language.HarvnbChloupekNekvapil199393–95
article.heading: Geographic distribution
article.paragraph: File:Languages of CE Europe.PNGthumbrightA map of the languages ofCentral EuropeCentralandEastern Europe. Within the Czech Republic, Standard Czech is represented by dark yellow (C1) andMoravian dialectsby medium yellow (C2) and light green (C3).alt=Eastern European countries are shown on a map. The Czech Republic, the westernmost of these, is shaped a bit like a jagged horizontal oval, and it is covered by the color representing the Czech language and, at its borders, a little by languages from Poland and Slovakia.File:Vojvodina rusyn croatian czech map.pngthumbrightalt=Map of Vojvodina, a province of Serbia, with Czech in official use in one southeastern municipalityOfficial use of Czech inVojvodina,SerbiaIn 2005 and 2007, Czech was spoken by about 10 million residents of theCzech Republic.HarvnbNaughton20052AEurobarometersurvey conducted from January to March 2012 found that thefirst languageof 98 percent of Czech citizens was Czech, the third-highest in theEuropean Union(behindGreeceandHungary).

Czech, the official language of the Czech Republic (a member of theEuropean Unionsince 2004), is one of the EU's official languages and the 2012 Eurobarometer survey found that Czech was the foreign language most often used in Slovakia.cite webPDFhttp://ec.europa.eu/public_opinion/archives/ebs/ebs_386_en.pdf[[Eurobarometer]]Europeans and Their LanguagesJune 2012July 25, 2014Economist Jonathan van Parys collected data on language knowledge in Europe for the 2012European Day of Languages. The five countries with the greatest use of Czech were theCzech Republic(98.77 percent),Slovakia(24.86 percent),Portugal(1.93 percent),Poland(0.98 percent) andGermany(0.47 percent).cite webhttp://languageknowledge.eu/languages/czechLanguage KnowledgeLanguage knowledge in the European Union2012van ParysJonathanJuly 23, 2014

Czech speakers in Slovakia primarily live in cities. Since it is a recognisedminority languagein Slovakia, Slovak citizens who speak only Czech may communicate with the government in their language to the extent that Slovak speakers in the Czech Republic may do so.cite webhttp://alppi.vedeckecasopisy.cz/publicFiles/00131.pdfPDFLanguage Policy of Slovak RepublicŠkrobákZdeněk''Annual of Language & Politics and Politics of Identity''July 26, 2014
article.heading: United States
article.paragraph: see alsoCzech AmericanCzech TexanImmigration of Czechs from Europe to theUnited Statesoccurred primarily from 1848 to 1914. Czech is aLess Commonly Taught LanguagesLess Commonly Taught Languagein U.S. schools, and is taught at Czech heritage centers. Large communities ofCzech Americanslive in the states ofTexas,NebraskaandWisconsin.cite webhttp://www.cal.org/heritage/pdfs/briefs/czech-language-programs-in-the-united-states.pdfPDF[[University of California, Berkeley]]HroudaSimone J.Czech Language Programs and Czech as a Heritage Language in the United StatesJuly 23, 2014In the2000 United States Census, Czech was reported as the most-commonLanguage Spoken at Home in the United States of Americalanguage spoken at home(besidesEnglish languageEnglish) inValley County, NebraskaValley,Butler County, NebraskaButlerandSaunders County, NebraskaSaundersCounty (United States)Counties, Nebraska andRepublic County, Kansas. With the exception ofSpanish languageSpanish(the non-English language most commonly spoken at home nationwide), Czech was the most-common home language in over a dozen additional counties in Nebraska, Kansas, Texas,North DakotaandMinnesota.cite webhttps://www.census.gov/population/www/cen2000/censusatlas/pdf/8_Language.pdfPDF[[United States Census|Census.gov]]Chapter 8: Language2000July 23, 2014As of 2009, 70,500 Americans spoke Czech as their first language (49th place nationwide, behindTurkish languageTurkishand ahead ofSwedish languageSwedish).cite webhttps://web.archive.org/web/20090220090800/http://www.usefoundation.org/userdata/file/Research/languages_of_the_usa.pdfhttp://www.usefoundation.org/userdata/file/Research/languages_of_the_usa.pdfFebruary 20, 2009[[U.S. English (organization)|U.S. English]]Languages of the U.S.A.PDFJuly 25, 2014no
article.heading: Dialects
article.paragraph: mainCommon CzechMoravian dialectsChod dialectLach dialectsIn addition to a spoken standard and a closely related written standard, Czech has several regional dialects primarily used in rural areas by speakers less proficient in other dialects or standard Czech. During the second half of the twentieth century, Czech dialect use began to weaken. By the early 1990s dialect use was stigmatized, associated with the shrinking lower class and used in literature or other media for comedic effect. Increased travel and media availability to dialect-speaking populations has encouraged them to shift to (or add to their own dialect) standard Czech.HarvnbEckert1993143–144Although Czech has received considerable scholarly interest for a Slavic language, this interest has focused primarily on modern standard Czech and ancient texts rather than dialects.HarvnbWilson200921Standard Czech is still the norm for politicians, businesspeople and other Czechs in formal situations, but Common Czech is gaining ground in journalism and the mass media.

A detailed 2003 estimate from theCzech Statistical Officecounts the following dialects:cite webMap of Czech Dialectshttp://www.osu.cz/fpd/kcd/dokumenty/cestinapositi/kuldanova/mapka_01.htm2003Český statistický úřad ([[Czech Statistical Office]])July 26, 2014

The main colloquial Czech dialect, spoken primarily nearPraguebut also throughout the country, is known asCommon Czech(obecn etina). This is an academic distinction; most Czechs are unaware of the term or associate it with vernacular (or incorrect) Czech.Compared to standard Czech, Common Czech is characterized by simpler inflection patterns and differences in sound distribution.cite webhttp://cat.inist.fr/?aModele[[Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic]]2003The present-day situation of CzechDanešFrantišekAugust 10, 2014yes

The Czech dialects spoken inMoraviaandSilesiaare known asMoravian dialectsMoravian(moravtina). In theAustro-Hungarian Empire, "Bohemian-Moravian-Slovak" was a language citizens could register as speaking (with German, Polish and several others).HarvnbKortmannvan der Auwera2011714Of the Czech dialects, only Moravian is distinguished in nationwide surveys by theCzech Statistical Office. As of 2011, 62,908 Czech citizens spoke Moravian as their first language and 45,561 wereDiglossiadiglossal(speaking Moravian and standard Czech as first languages).cite webhttp://vdb.czso.cz/sldbvo/#!strankaČeský statistický úřad (Czech Statistical Office)March 26, 2011July 26, 2014Tab. 614b Obyvatelstvo podle věku, mateřského jazyka a pohlaví (Population by Age, Mother Tongue, and Gender)Czech

Beginning in the sixteenth century, some varieties of Czech resembled Slovak;the southeastern Moravian dialects, in particular, are sometimes considered dialects of Slovak rather than Czech. These dialects form a continuum between the Czech and Slovak languages,HarvnbKortmannvan der Auwera2011516using the same declension patterns for nouns and pronouns and the same verb conjugations as Slovak.cite webharvŠustekZbyšekOtázka kodifikace spisovného moravského jazyka (The question of codifying a written Moravian language)[[University of Tartu]]1998http://www.britskelisty.cz/9809/19980914d.htmlcsJuly 21, 2014
In a 1964 textbook on Czechdialectology, Betislav Koudela used the following sentence to highlight phonetic differences between dialects:HarvnbKoudela1964173

tablerow.tablecell: Put the flour from the mill into the cart.

article.heading: Phonology
article.paragraph: mainCzech phonologyCzech contains ten basicvowelphonemes, and three more found only inloanwords. They areIPA/a/, /ɛ/, /ɪ/, /o/, and /u/, their long counterpartsIPA/aː/, /ɛː/, /iː/, /oː/ and /uː/, and three diphthongs,IPA/ou̯/, /au̯/ and /ɛu̯/. The latter two diphthongs and the longIPA/oː/are exclusive to loanwords.HarvnbDankovičová199972Vowels are never reduced toschwasounds when unstressed.HarvnbHarkins19529Each word usually has primarystress (linguistics)stresson its firstsyllable, except forenclitics(minor, monosyllabic, unstressed words). In all words of more than two syllables, every odd-numbered syllable receives secondary stress. Stress is unrelated to vowel length, and the possibility of stressed short vowels and unstressed long vowels can be confusing to students whose native language combines the features (such as English).HarvnbHarkins195212

Voice (phonetics)Voicedconsonantswith unvoiced counterparts are unvoiced at the end of a word, or when they are followed by unvoiced consonants.HarvnbHarkins195210–11Czech consonants are categorized as "hard", "neutral" or "soft":

This distinction describes theCzech declensiondeclensionpatterns of nouns, which is based on the category of a noun's ending consonant. Hard consonants may not be followed byiorin writing, or soft ones byyor(except in loanwords such askilogramand a few declined nouns:tctakes the pluraltcy).cite webPsaní i – y po písmenu chttp://prirucka.ujc.cas.cz/en/?idCzech Language Institute11 August 2014Neutral consonants may take either character. Hard consonants are sometimes known as "strong", and soft ones as "weak".HarvnbHarkins195211

The phoneme represented by the letter(capital) is considered unique to Czech.It represents theraised alveolar non-sonorant trill(International Phonetic AlphabetIPA:IPA[r̝]), a sound somewhere between Czech'srand(example:audioCs-řeka.ogg"řeka" (river)),HarvnbHarkins19526and is present inDvok.

The consonantsIPA/r/ and /l/can besyllabic consonantsyllabic, acting assyllable nucleiin place of a vowel. This can be difficult for non-native speakers to pronounce, andStr prst skrz krk("Stick [your] finger down [your] throat") is a Czechtongue twister.HarvnbNaughton20055
article.heading: Vocabulary
article.paragraph: see alsoList of English words of Czech originCzech vocabulary derives primarily from Slavic, Baltic and other Indo-European roots. Although most verbs have Balto-Slavic origins, pronouns, prepositions and some verbs have wider, Indo-European roots.HarvnbMann1957159Some loanwords have been restructured byfolk etymologyto resemble native Czech words (wikt:hbitovhbitov, "graveyard" andwikt:listinalistina, "list").HarvnbMann1957160

Most Czech loanwords originated in one of two time periods. Earlier loanwords, primarily from German,HarvnbMathesius201320Greek languageGreekand Latin,HarvnbSussexCubberley2011101arrived before the Czech National Revival. More recent loanwords derive primarily from English andFrench languageFrench,and also fromHebrew languageHebrew,Arabic languageArabicandPersian languagePersian. Many Russian loanwords, principally animal names and naval terms, also exist in Czech.HarvnbMann1957159–160

Although older German loanwords were colloquial, recent borrowings from other languages are associated with high culture.During the nineteenth century, words with Greek and Latin roots were rejected in favor of those based on older Czech words and common Slavic roots; "music" iswikt:muzykamuzykain Polish and(muzyka) in Russian, but in Czech it iswikt:hudbahudba.Some Czech words have been borrowed as loanwords intoList of English words of Czech originEnglishand other languagesfor example,robot(fromwikt:robotarobota, "labor")cite webhttp://www.etymonline.com/index.php?termOnline Etymology Dictionaryrobot (n.)HarperDouglasJuly 22, 2014andpolka(fromwikt:polkapolka, "Polish peoplePolishwoman" or from "plka" "half").cite webhttp://www.etymonline.com/index.php?termOnline Etymology Dictionarypolka (n.)HarperDouglasJuly 22, 2014
article.heading: Grammar
article.paragraph: Typical of Indo-European languages, Czech grammar isfusional languagefusional; its nouns, verbs, and adjectives areinflectioninflectedby phonological processes to modify their meanings and grammatical functions, and the easily separableaffixescharacteristic ofagglutinative languageagglutinativelanguages are limited.HarvnbQualls20126–8Slavic-language inflection is complex and pervasive, inflecting for case, gender and number in nouns and tense, aspect,Grammatical moodmood, person and subject number and gender in verbs.HarvnbQualls20125

Other parts of speech include adjectives,adverbs, numbers,interrogative words,prepositions,conjunction (grammar)conjunctionsandinterjections.HarvnbNaughton2005v–viiiAdverbs are primarily formed by taking the finalorof an adjective and replacing it withe,, oro.HarvnbNaughton200561–63Negative statements are formed by adding the affixwikt:ne#Czechne-to the verb of a clause, with one exception:je(he, she or it is) becomesnen.HarvnbNaughton2005212
article.heading: Sentence and clause structure
article.paragraph: Because Czech usesgrammatical caseto convey word function in a sentence (instead of relying onword order, as English does), its word order is flexible. As apro-drop language, in Czech anTransitivity (grammar)intransitivesentence can consist of only a verb; information about its subject is encoded in the verb.HarvnbNaughton200574Enclitics (primarilyauxiliary verbsand pronouns) must appear in the second syntactic slot of a sentence, after the first stressed unit. The first slot must contain a subject and object, a main form of a verb, an adverb or a conjunction (except for the light conjunctionsa, "and",i, "and even" orale, "but").sfnShort2009324

Czech syntax has asubjectverbobjectsentence structure. In practice, however, word order is flexible and used fortopicalizationand focus. Although Czech has aPeriphrasisperiphrasticPassive voicepassiveconstruction (like English), colloquial word-order changes frequently produce the passive voice. For example, to change "Peter killedPaul" to "Paul was killed by Peter" the order of subject and object is inverted:Petr zabil Pavla("Peter killed Paul") becomes "Paul, Peter killed" (Pavla zabil Petr).Pavlais in theaccusative case, the grammatical object (in this case, the victim) of the verb.sfnShort2009325
A word at the end of a clause is typically emphasized, unless an upwardintonation (linguistics)intonationindicates that the sentence is a question:HarvnbNaughton200510–11

list.listitem: Pes j bagetu.The dog eats the baguette (rather than eating something else).
Bagetu j pes.The dog eats the baguette (rather than someone else doing so).
Pes bagetu j.The dog eats the baguette (rather than doing something else to it).
J pes bagetu?Does the dog eat the baguette? (emphasis ambiguous)

article.paragraph: In portions ofBohemia(includingPrague), questions such asJ pes bagetu?without an interrogative word (such asco, "what" orkdo, "who") areIntonation (linguistics)intonedin a slow rise from low to high, quickly dropping to low on the last word or phrase.HarvnbNaughton200510

In Czech syntax, adjectives precede nouns.HarvnbNaughton200548Relative clausesare introduced byrelativizerssuch as the adjectivekter, analogous to the Englishrelative pronouns"which", "that", "who" and "whom". As with other adjectives, it is declined into the appropriate case (see#DeclensionDeclension below) to match its associated noun, person and number. Relative clauses follow the noun they modify, and the following is aInterlinear glossglossedexample:HarvnbHarkins1952271
English:I want to visit the university that John attends.
article.heading: Declension
article.paragraph: MainCzech declensionIn Czech, nouns and adjectives are declined into one of seven grammatical cases. Nouns are inflected to indicate their use in a sentence. Anominativeaccusative language, Czech marks subject nouns with nominative case and object nouns with accusative case. The genitive case marks possessive nouns and some types of movement. The remaining cases (instrumental, locative, vocative and dative) indicate semantic relationships, such as secondary objects, movement or position (dative case) and accompaniment (instrumental case). An adjective's case agrees with that of the noun it describes. When Czech children learn their language's declension patterns, the cases are referred to by number:HarvnbNaughton200525

tablerow.tablecell: Belonging, movement away from something (or someone)
Indirect objects, movement toward something (or someone)
Being used for a task; acting with someone (or something)

article.paragraph: Some Czech grammatical texts order the cases differently, grouping the nominative and accusative (and the dative and locative) together because those declension patterns are often identical; this order accommodates learners with experience in other inflected languages, such as Latin orRussian languageRussian. This order is nominative, accusative, genitive, dative, locative, instrumental and vocative.

Some prepositions require the nouns they modify to take a particular case. The cases assigned by each preposition are based on the physical (or metaphorical) direction, or location, conveyed by it. For example,wikt:odod(from, away from) andwikt:z#Czechz(out of, off) assign the genitive case. Other prepositions take one of several cases, with their meaning dependent on the case;wikt:na#Czechnameans "onto" or "for" with the accusative case, but "on" with the locative.HarvnbNaughton2005201–205
Examples of declension patterns (using prepositions) for a few nouns with adjectives follow. Only one plural example is given, since plural declension patterns are similar across genders.

tablerow.tablecell:
z velkho psa
(from the big dog)

z mal koky
(from the small cat)

z tvrdho deva
(from the hard wood)

z mladch drak
(from the young dragons)

k velkmu psovi
(to the big dog)

k mal koce
(to the small cat)

ke tvrdmu devu
(to the hard wood)

ke mladm drakm
(to the young dragons)

na velkho psa
(for the big dog)

na malou koku
(for the small cat)

na tvrd devo
(for the hard wood)

na mlad draky
(for the young dragons)

o velkm psovi
(about the big dog)

o mal koce
(about the small cat)

o tvrdm dev
(about the hard wood)

o mladch dracch
(about the young dragons)

s velkm psem
(with the big dog)

s malou kokou
(with the small cat)

s tvrdm devem
(with the hard wood)

s mladmi draky
(with the young dragons)

article.paragraph: This is a glossed example of a sentence using several cases:
English:I carried the box into the house with my friend.
article.heading: Gender and animacy
article.paragraph: Czech distinguishes threegrammatical gendergendersmasculine, feminine, and neuterand the masculine gender is subdivided intoanimacyanimateand inanimate. With few exceptions, feminine nouns in the nominative case end in-a,-e, or-ost; neuter nouns in-o,-e, or-, and masculine nouns in a consonant.HarvnbNaughton200522–24Adjectives agree in gender and animacy (for masculine nouns in the accusative or genitive singular and the nominative plural) with the nouns they modify.HarvnbNaughton200551The main effect of gender in Czech is the difference in noun and adjective declension, but other effects include past-tense verb endings: for example,dlal(he did, or made);dlala(she did, or made) anddlalo(it did, or made).HarvnbNaughton2005141
article.heading: Number
article.paragraph: Nouns are also inflected forgrammatical numbernumber, distinguishing between singular and plural. Typical of a Slavic language, Czech cardinal numbers one through four allow the nouns and adjectives they modify to take any case, but numbers over five place these nouns and adjectives in the genitive case when the entire expression is in nominative or accusative case. TheCzech korunais an example of this feature; it is shown here as the subject of a hypothetical sentence, and declined as genitive for numbers five and up.HarvnbNaughton2005114

Numerical words decline for case and, for numbers one and two, for gender. Numbers one through five are shown below as examples, and have some of the most exceptions among Czech numbers. The number one has declension patterns identical to those of thedemonstrative pronoun,wikt:to#Czechto.HarvnbNaughton200583HarvnbNaughton2005117

tablerow.tablecell:
jednoho(male an.)
jeden(male in.)
jednu(female)
jedno(neuter)

article.paragraph: Although Czech's maingrammatical numbersare singular andplural, a vestigialdual (grammatical number)dualnumber remains. Some nouns for paired body parts have a dual form:wikt:rukaruka(hand)ruce;wikt:nohanoha(leg)nohy;wikt:okooko(eye)oi, andwikt:uchoucho(ear)ui. While two of these nouns are neuter in their singular forms, all dual nouns are considered feminine. Czech has no standard declension pattern for dual nouns, and their gender is relevant to their associated adjectives and verbs.HarvnbNaughton200540
article.heading: Verb conjugation
article.paragraph: MainCzech conjugationMorphological classification of Czech verbsCzech verb conjugation is less complex than noun and adjective declension because it codes for fewer categories. Verbs agree with their subjects ingrammatical personperson(first, second or third) andgrammatical numbernumber(singular or plural), and are conjugated for tense (past, present orfuture tensefuture). For example, the conjugated verbwikt:mluvitmluvme(we speak) is in the present tense and first-person plural; it is distinguished from other conjugations of theinfinitivemluvitby its ending,me.
article.heading: Aspect
article.paragraph: See alsoGrammatical aspect in Slavic languagesTypical of Slavic languages, Czech marks its verbs for one of twogrammatical aspects:perfective aspectperfectiveandimperfective aspectimperfective. Most verbs are part of inflected aspect pairsfor example,wikt:koupitkoupit(perfective) andwikt:kupovatkupovat(imperfective). Although the verbs' meaning is similar, in perfective verbs the action is completed and in imperfective verbs it is ongoing. This is distinct frompast tensepastandpresent tense,HarvnbNaughton2005146and any Czech verb of either aspect can be conjugated into any of its three tenses.HarvnbNaughton2005131Aspect describes the state of the action at the time specified by the tense.

The verbs of most aspect pairs differ in one of two ways: by prefix or by suffix. In prefix pairs, the perfective verb has an added prefixfor example, the imperfectivepst(to write, to be writing) compared with the perfectivenapsat(to write down, to finish writing). The most common prefixes arena-,o-,po-,s-,u-,vy-,z-andza-.HarvnbNaughton2005147In suffix pairs, a different infinitive ending is added to the perfective stem; for example, the perfective verbskoupit(to buy) andprodat(to sell) have the imperfective formskupovatandprodvat.HarvnbNaughton2005147–148Imperfective verbs may undergo further morphology to make other imperfective verbs (iterative andfrequentativeforms), denoting repeated or regular action. The verbjt(to go) has the iterative formchodit(to go repeatedly) and the frequentative formchodvat(to go regularly).cite webLukešDominikDominikLukeš.netGramatická terminologie ve vyučování - Terminologie a platonický svět gramatických idejíhttp://www.dominiklukes.net/bibliography/platonickysvetgramatickychkategoriiAugust 5, 20142001

Many verbs have only one aspect, and verbs describing continual states of beingwikt:btbt(to be),wikt:chttchtt(to want),wikt:moctmoct(to be able to),wikt:leetleet(to lie down, to be lying down)have no perfective form. Conversely, verbs describing immediate states of changefor example,wikt:othotntothotnt(to become pregnant) andwikt:nadchnout senadchnout se(to become enthusiastic)have no imperfective aspect.HarvnbNaughton2005149
article.heading: Tense and mood
article.paragraph: Although Czech's use of present and future tense is largely similar to that of English, the language uses past tense to represent the Englishpresent perfectandPluperfectpast perfect;ona belacould meanshe ran,she has runorshe had run.HarvnbNaughton2005140

In some contexts, Czech's perfective present (which differs from the Englishpresent perfect) implies future action; in others, it connotes habitual action.HarvnbNaughton2005150As a result, the language has a proper future tense to minimize ambiguity. The future tense does not involve conjugating the verb describing an action to be undertaken in the future; instead, the future form ofbt(as shown in the table at left) is placed before the infinitive (for example,budu jst"I will eat").HarvnbNaughton2005151

This conjugation is not followed bybtitself, so future-oriented expressions involving nouns, adjectives, or prepositions (rather than verbs) omitbt. "I will be happy" is translated asBudu astn(notBudu bt astn).

The infinitive form ends int(archaically,ti). It is the form found in dictionaries and the form that follows auxiliary verbs (for example,mu t slyet"I canhearyou").HarvnbNaughton20057Czech verbs have threegrammatical moods:indicative,imperative moodimperativeandconditional moodconditional.HarvnbRothsteinThieroff2010359The imperative mood adds specific endings for each of three person (or number) categories:-/-i/-ejfor second-person singular,-te/-ete/-ejtefor second-person plural and-me/-eme/-ejmefor first-person plural.HarvnbNaughton2005157The conditional mood is formed with aGrammatical particleparticleafter the past-tense verb. This mood indicates possible events, expressed in English as "I would" or "I wish".HarvnbNaughton2005152–154Clear
article.heading: Classes
article.paragraph: Most Czech verbs fall into one of fivemorphological classification of Czech verbsclasses, which determine their conjugation patterns. The future tense ofbtwould be classified as a Class I verb because of its endings. Examples of the present tense of each class and some common irregular verbs follow in the tables below:HarvnbNaughton2005136–140
article.heading: Orthography
article.paragraph: File:Psac psmo.gifthumbright300pxThe handwritten Czech alphabetmainCzech orthographysee alsoCzech BrailleCzech has one of the mostPhonemic orthographyphonemic orthographiesof all European languages. Its thirty-onegraphemesrepresent thirty sounds (in most dialects,iandyhave the same sound), and it contains only onedigraph (orthography)digraph:ch, which followshin the alphabet.HarvnbPansofia199311As a result, some of its characters have been used by phonologists to denote corresponding sounds in other languages. The charactersq,wandxappear only in foreign words.HarvnbHarkins19521Thehek() is used with certain letters to form new characters:,, and, as well as,,,, and(the latter five uncommon outside Czech). The last two letters are sometimes written with a comma above (, an abbreviated hek) because of their height.HarvnbHarkins19526–8The characterexists only in loanwords andonomatopoeia.HarvnbHarkins19528

Unlike most European languages, Czech distinguishesvowel length; long vowels are indicated by anacute accentor, occasionally with, aring (diacritic)ring. Longuis usually writtenat the beginning of a word or morpheme (roda,nerodn) andelsewhere,HarvnbHarkins19527except for loanwords (sktr) or onomatopoeia (b).HarvnbPansofia199326Long vowels andare not considered separate letters.HarvnbHajičová198631

Czechtypographytypographicalfeatures not associated with phonetics generally resemble those of mostLatin alphabetLatinEuropean languages, including English.Proper nouns,honorificsand the first letters of quotations arecapitalizationcapitalized, andpunctuationis typical of other Latin European languages. An unusual feature is the marking of thousands inArabic numerals; the millions place (and all higher places) receive commas, the thousands place receives a period and the ones place (precedingdecimals) receives a mid-height period similar to abullet point. For example, 20,671,634.09 in English orthography would be 20,671.63409 in Czech.HarvnbHarkins195214–15Another difference is that inproper nounphrases (except personal names), only the first word is capitalized (Prask hrad,Prague Castle).HarvnbNaughton200511HarvnbPansofia199334
article.heading: Sample text
article.paragraph: File:Presl brambor.JPGthumbright1846 sample of printed CzechAccording to Article 1 of the United NationsUniversal Declaration of Human Rights:

Czech:Vichni lid se rod svobodn a sob rovn co do dstojnosti a prv. Jsou nadni rozumem a svdomm a maj spolu jednat v duchu bratrstv.cite webVšeobecná deklarace lidských pravhttp://www.osn.cz/dokumenty-osn/soubory/vseobecna-deklarace-lidskych-prav.pdfhttp://www.webcitation.org/6XmagF9fj2015-04-14United Nations Information Centre PragueUnited NationsJuly 30, 2014PDF

English: "All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights. They are endowed with reason and conscience and should act towards one another in a spirit of brotherhood."cite webhttp://www.un.org/Overview/rights.htmlThe Universal Declaration of Human RightsUnited NationsDecember 10, 2014https://web.archive.org/web/20141208080853/http://www.un.org/Overview/rights.htmlDecember 8, 2014
